Maximiliana de 55 años, es una madre soltera. Vive con su único hijo Maycon en una casa propia ubicada en un barrio agrícola.Ella tiene mucho coraje y fuerza para el trabajo duro. Supo sacar adelante a su hijo quien ahora es mayor y la ayuda en sus labores del campo. Ella es una mujer agricultora y a su edad ya sabe como funciona el negocio. Los productos que con tanto esfuerzo y dedicación ha logrado cultivar le han ayudado mucho en el progreso de su vida. Su trabajo inicia desde antes que salga el sol, cuidando a sus animales pues también cría: cuyes, gallinas, toros y ovejas; luego se dirige a limpiar y cuidar sus cultivos.Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es atender sus tierras y se siente bien al ver sus arvejas, habas, maíz, papas y hortalizas crecer sanas.
“Cuando cosecho vendo mis productos en el mercado mayorista de Tarma”, comenta y a su vez espera mejorar sus productos, para así poder obtener mayores ganacias.
Ahora se encuentra en la preparación de un terreno para sembrar maíz, por ello requiere de su ayuda.
Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Señor de Muruhuay” y éste sería su crédito número 6 con MFP. Está dispuesta a pagar con puntualidad las cuotas mensuales. En su banco comunal es una socia muy solidaria y colaboradora.Con los 2500 soles podrá comprar semillas de maíz, y varias bolsas de abono orgánico.
texts.en:
Maximiliana is 55 years old and is a single mother.  She lives with her only son, Maycon, in her own home located in a farming neighborhood.  She has lots of courage and effort for hard work.  She knew how to get her son ahead and he helps her with her farm work.  She is a farmer and at her age she knows how the business works.  The products that she has raised with so much effort and dedication have helped her in her life.  Her work begins before the sun comes up, caring for her animals.  She also raises Guinea pigs, chickens, bulls, and sheep.  The she goes out to clean and care for her crops.  What she likes most about her work is tending to her land and she feels good watcher her peas, beans, corn, potatoes, and vegetables grow healthily.

“When I harvest, I sell my products in the main market in Tarma,” she says, and she hopes to improve her products so that she can obtain better earnings.

Now she is preparing to plant corn and needs your help.  She is a member of the “Señor de Muruhuay” communal bank and this will he her sixth loan through MFP.  She is prepared to make her monthly payments on schedule.  She is very cooperative in her communal bank.  She will use the 2,500 PEN from this loan to buy corn seeds and bags of compost.

loans.use: to buy seeds and compost.

loans.name: Shienyu Ni Shienyu Group

texts.en:
Monica is pictured on the right with her hand raised among her Shienyu ni Shienyu Group members. The twelve members, nine women and three men, are farmers in Kakamega South District. Farming inputs consisting of the materials necessary to plant half an acre of maize, millet, and sorghum will be delivered to her on credit. Monica joined One Acre Fund during the "long rains" season of 2010 and is now enrolling for the 2013 "long rains" season. Monica joined One Acre Fund so that she could gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and access the best input prices.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Monica was only able to harvest two bags of maize per half acre, but after joining One Acre Fund, she was able to harvest eight bags per half acre during the "long rains" of 2012. She plans to use her profits from the harvest to send her children to school and save for the future. For the 2013 "long rains" season, Monica’s group members will each take part of the loan to plant on half an acre of land. In total, this group will receive a loan for enough inputs to use on six acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Rosette

texts.en: Rosette is married and has four children, three of whom attend school. She does not take care of additional family members. She has a business selling charcoal. She has been in this business for seven years, selling to all categories of people on a retail basis. She has applied for a loan of 500,000 UGX from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bags of charcoal. She works in a shop that she rents seven days a week.  Her major business challenges include transportation and seasonality. She aspires to become a wholesaler and also to buy a delivery van for easier transportation. She resides in a rented house; the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent, school fees, and food.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Nzalambi

texts.en:
Nzalambi is 51 years old and has been married to her husband, Chagamba, for years. She has five children, all of whom are adults.

Nzalambi has run a kiosk for three years, and thanks her husband, who works as a businessman, for his help. Together they help one another with the family expenses. 

She is asking for this loan to buy noodles, flour, cooking oil, herbs, cookies, cassava, drinks and candy to stock in her store. Nzalambi will then offer a greater variety to her customers and be able to increase her income.

loans.use: to buy noodles, flour, cooking oil, herbs, cookies, cassava, drinks and candy to sell in her kiosk.

loans.name: Baraka Group

texts.en:
Mika is a member of the Baraka Group, which has 16 farmers in total and is located in Kakamega South District, Kenya. Mika is pictured on the right with his hand raised.  He will receive input loans capable of planting a half of an acre with sorghum, millet, and maize. Mika first enrolled with the One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Mika joined to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and grow enough food for the family.

Mika reports that he grew about a bag of maize per acre in past seasons, but with his One Acre Fund input loan last year, he harvested 13 bags per 1 ½ acre. He hopes that his profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send his children to school and to repair his home. For this coming season, each group member will receive a half of an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Mika’s group will receive eight acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Shee

texts.en:
Shee is a married man who lives with his wife and nine children in the village of Mwambalazi. Before he started his store, Shee raised livestock and was able to accumulate a significant amount of capital. He built his house and decided to open a store with their savings. Thanks to his effort and hard work, the business has expanded. Shee now has a steady clientele because of the good and friendly service he provides to his customers.

Shee is requesting a loan to purchase supplies for his store, such as beverages, groceries, vegetables and other products.

loans.use: to purchase supplies for his store such as beverages, groceries, vegetables and other products.

loans.name: Willinton

texts.es: Wilinton  de 28 años de edad se dedica  ala elaboración de pizzas y jugos, experiencia que adquirió hace 6 años, cuando trabajó para el propietario de ese mismo negocio, que le fue vendido por su propietario,  al ver la responsabilidad propia de Willington; Hoy que ha organizado su hogar del cual existe un hijo de 3 años de edad y ha logrado sostener su microempresa  con mucho trabajo, pues es dedicado, tiene un puesto donde llegan sus clientes, compran diariamente los insumos para elaborar productos de pizzería y jugos naturales, con los cuales deleita a su clientela. En la actualidad está aplicando aun credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace ala Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará salsas, cárnicos, un carrito para transportar arepas . Sus principales clientes son sus vecinos, gran parte de los cuales provienen de su pueblo natal y son fieles a él, pues trabaja efectivamente con el fin de lograr impactarlos. Su meta mas adelante es adquirir una casa ´propia manteniendo su fuente de ingresos que es muy apropiada para alcanzar sus metas, pero eso si haciéndolo crecer cada vez mas.
texts.en:
Wilinton is 28 years old. He works making pizzas and juices. He has six years experience. He learned when he worked for the owner of the same business, which was sold to him by its owner, upon seeing Willington’s sense of duty. 

Today he has started his own household and he has a three year old son and has managed to sustain his micro-enterprise with a lot of hard work. He is dedicated. He has a stand where customers visit. He buys supplies daily in order to make pizza and natural juices, which pleases his customers.

Currently he is asking for a Kiva loan, his first financing being made through Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, in order to buy salsas, meat, and a cart to transport tortillas.

His main clients are neighbors, many of who come from his hometown and are faithful to him, as he works energetically in order to successfully influence them. His goal for the future is to buy his own house, maintaining income that is adequate in order to achieve his goals, and by doing this to grow more and more.

loans.use: to buy salsas, meat, and a cart to transport tortillas

loans.name: Lojuan

texts.en: Lojuan benefited from his previous loans, but how has changed his business from selling clothing to selling hardware due to acquiring enough working capital. He has bought cement, nails, etc. and is now taking a new loan to purchase more items to increase his stock. Lojuan is happy for the loan.

loans.use: to purchase more items like cement and nails to sell.

loans.name: Bakari

texts.en:
Bakari is a single man from the village of Mwambalazi. He is the owner of a store in his private house and he has regular customers. He also makes deliveries door to door. He sells coconuts. He is a hard worker whose goal is to be able to continue growing to be able to continue helping his family and to take care of the day to day expenses.

He is requesting this loan to be able to purchase supplies for his store and thus continue working and earning more.

loans.use: to purchase supplies for his store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothing materials and to pay for her child's school fees.

loans.name: Hidaya

texts.en:
Hidaya is a 34-year-old hardworking lady married to Hamadi and blessed with two children, a boy and a girl, who are both in school. Their major monthly expenditures are school fees and rent. She earns her living through buying and selling clothes from house to house, a business that she has been running for the last two years. This has enabled her to cater to customers and have her own share in the competitive business.

Due to growth of her customer base, there is a need to open her own stall to reduce the cost of moving from house to house and instead reinvest on the business. To buy a bundle of cloth is why she approached Yehu where she has been a member for more than a year now. She is requesting a loan amounting to 25,000 KES. She is grateful for the opportunity.

loans.use: to open her own stall.

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica is a married woman with three children. She describes herself as a focused woman. She operates a retail store where she sells clothing. Veronica has been involved in this business for five years with her primary customers being local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge is insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy clothing to sell. Her business goal is to run a boutique in five years. She hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy clothing to sell in her store.

loans.name: Daniela

texts.es: La Sra. Daniela  tiene 33 años, tiene tres hijos de las edades de 1, 5  y 8 años, ella se dedica a la venta de rellenos Benianos que son  un bocadito que generalmente se sirve  a media mañana, ella vende  en su puesto de venta que se encuentra  en la zona de Satélite  este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución, la Sra. Daniela  va a usar este préstamo para la compra de un frízer y mantener refrigerados sus productos,  su razón para solicitar este préstamo es seguir mejorando en su  negocio. La Sra. Daniela  es una persona muy trabajadora se siente feliz por la oportunidad brindada ya que esta es la única actividad que le permite mantener a su familia.
texts.en: Daniela is 33 years old.  She has three children, ages 1, 5 and 8.  She works selling “rellenos Benianos” which are a snack generally served in the mid-morning.  She sells in her stall that is located in the Satélite area.  This loan is her first sequence within the institution.  Daniela is going to use this loan to purchase a freezer and to keep her products refrigerated.  Her reason for applying for this loan is to continue improving in her business.  Daniela is a very hardworking person.  She feels happy for the opportunity offered to her since this is the only activity that allows her to support her family.

loans.use: to purchase a freezer.

loans.name: Claribel

texts.es: Claribel de 49 años de edad vive en Puerto Colombia, municipio ubicado a orillas del mar, con su esposo y sus dos hijos en las edades de 29 y 30 años. Desde hace 4 años se dedica al comercio, actividad con la que genera ingresos que apoyan el bienestar de su familia. Sus principales productos son los cosméticos de diversas marcas pues trabaja mediante el sistema de catálogos, es decir hace sus promociones con 4 guías especializadas de productos provenientes de multinacionales con las que establece sus relaciones comerciales. En su estrategia aborda el mercado de Puerto Colombia y también tiene clientes en la ciudad e Barranquilla ubicada a 20 minutos, ella para entregar el producto solicita el 50% y da crédito por el resto del valor de los productos que cada cliente escoja, teniendo en cuenta un plan de pagos que establece con cada uno, no mayor a 30 días. Gradualmente sus solicitudes de pedidos se incrementan especialmente en las temporadas especiales, como la que ocurre próximamente, cuando celebraron las familias el día de la madres. En su casa siempre cuenta con un inventario de productos que más rotan, para que sus clientes cuando le soliciten no se vayan con las manos vacías, pues siempre aprovecha las ofertas que traen las revistas, para impactar su mercado. Entre sus metas está el de organizar un pequeño almacén y por esto ha planeado su credikiva, segundo financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el primer financiamiento compró una vitrina metálica para organizar su inventario y productos que han sido solicitado por su clientela, como perfumes, accesorios femeninos, artículos de bisutería etc. La razón de éxito de su inversión es su gran experiencia, la oportunidad de comprar promociones en mayores cantidades, y que la realiza  justamente en una temporada donde las ventas se incrementan por efecto de los días especiales como los carnavales, por eso acude a un credikiva con el comprará colonias, perfumes cremas, cosméticos, desodorantes, ropa interior femenina
texts.en:
Claribel, 49 years old, lives in Puerto Colombia, a municipality located on the shores of the sea, with her husband and their two children who are 29 and 30 years old.  For four years she has made a living in commerce, an activity with which she generates income that supports the well-being of her family.  Her main products are various brands of cosmetics as she works through a system of catalogues, that is to say she makes her promotions with 4 specialized product guides coming from multinational companies with which she establishes her business relations.  In her strategy she deals with the market of Puerto Colombia and also she has customers in the city of Barranquilla, located 20 minutes away.  In order to deliver the products she requests 50% and gives credit for the rest of the value of the products that each customer chooses, taking into account a payment plan that she establishes with each one, not exceeding 30 days.  Gradually, her requests for orders increases, particularly in the special seasons, like the one which occurs soon, when families celebrate Mothers' Day.  In her house she always has an inventory of the products that rotate more, so that her clients, when they ask her for something, aren’t leaving empty-handed.  She always takes advantage of the offers that the magazines carry, in order to have an impact on her market.  

Among her goals is that of organizing a small storehouse and for this she has planned her Kiva loan, her second financing made from the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  With the first financing she bought a metal display cabinet to organize her inventory and products that have been requested by her clientele, such as perfumes, feminine accessories, items of costume jewelry, etc.  The reason for the success of her investment is her great experience, the opportunity to purchase special offers in greater quantities and that she makes them precisely in the season where the sales are increased as a result of the special days like carnivals.  That is why she turns to a Kiva loan with which she will buy colognes, perfumes, creams, cosmetics, deodorants and feminine undergarments.

loans.use: to purchase colognes, perfumes, creams, cosmetics, deodorants and feminine undergarments.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is from Mwambalazi and is married with six children. She is the owner of a cafe selling drinks and has her own shop. She is a very hardworking, responsible and honest person.

Fatuma started with a small stand where she sold fast food such as dumplings, flat bread, sandwiches and other items, as well as ice and drinks in general.

Her dream was always to have a very spacious cafe so that she can offer good service to each one of her customers. Now, thanks to her efforts, and also the help that Yehu Microfinance Trust offers, she has her own cafe.

She is applying for this loan in order to buy more products for her store. This way she can meet the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy more products for her store.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is a 51-year-old widower who lives with his son and daughter in Vanadzor, Armenia. Both of Robert’s children are students at the State Armenian Pedagogical University. Robert graduated from there, too, and worked as teacher for more than nine years. Robert had to change his occupation due to low teacher pay since he is the only bread winner. 

Robert has run his own business for ten years, selling foodstuffs and household goods trading in a rented place. He obtains a part of his merchandise from suppliers and another part he buys from Yerevan wholesale markets. 

With the profit Robert earns from his business, he cares for his family’s needs and pays his children’s tuition fees. Robert believes that the main contribution for any Armenian parent is for their children’s education. He does his best to provide a good future for his children. 

To increase his income, Robert needs a 300,000 AMD loan to add to his foodstuffs and household goods inventory.

loans.use: to purchase more foodstuffs and household goods to sell in his shop.

loans.name: Protasia

texts.en:
Protasia lives in the village of Mwambalazi. She is married and has three children. She is the owner of a well-stocked general store which she has had for over seven years. It is worth noting that she works with her whole family, and it is going very well. Thanks to this business and the work of the entire family, they have been able to grow considerably and are continuing to grow. They want to be able to expand their shop until they have a large supermarket where they might offer greater variety and comfort to their customers.

Protasia is seeking this loan for the purchase of drinks, bakery items, vegetables, fruits, meat and other products in order to be able to keep providing a good variety to her customers since that is what draws them the most.

loans.use: to purchase drinks, bakery items, vegetables, fruits, meat and other products.

loans.name: Nadzua

texts.en:
Nadzua is 40 years old and married to Mwero. They have six school-aged children. They buy, package, and sell hardwood charcoal. At first they bought the charcoal already packaged, but later they were able to expand their storage area and now they can store up to 15,000 kg of charcoal. They buy bags and polyurethane, package the charcoal, and sell it to small businesses in the zone. They make their sales from a small cart.

They need this loan to buy charcoal, because they are increasing their number of customers and need to increase their inventory of charcoal to meet their demands. Their greatest desire is to provide an education for their children, so that they can guarantee them a prosperous future.

loans.use: to buy charcoal for resale

loans.name: Sofia

texts.en:
Sofia is a very hardworking person.  She has already applied for a Kiva loan in the past, which she used to buy items for her store.  She comments that the loan has been a great help to her, and it is for this reason that she is applying for a new loan.

She wants this loan in order to continue stocking her store with more products.  Since her busy season is getting close, she wants to buy beverages, canned goods, food, and other items.  She appreciates the opportunity that she is once more receiving, since this will enable her to grow and continue helping her family.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages, and food items for her store.

loans.name: Upendo Group

texts.en:
Rose is a member of the Upendo Group in Kakamega, South District.  She is pictured with 12 One Acre Fund farmers, 10 women and 2 men.  Rose is standing on the right with her hand raised.  She is receiving an input loan for ½ an acre of maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation.  Rose first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2010 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season.  Rose joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and access the best input prices.

Rose reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about 4 bags of maize per acre.  However, with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested 15 bags per acre. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and to repair her home.  For the 2013 Long Rains season, Rose’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each.  In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 6 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 37 years old. She lives in the village of Mwambalazi. She is married and has 7 children who attend school. Beatrice has a well-stocked store where she sells at retail. She is a hardworking and responsible person who is getting ahead with her hard work. Thanks to her work, she has given her children what they need to have a dignified life without deprivation.

She is asking for this loan to buy vegetables, fruit, dairy products, baked goods and more. She says that her goal is to be able to keep growing with her business and keep gaining customers.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, fruit, dairy products, baked goods and other items.

loans.name: Ngerechi

texts.en:
Ngerechi is a married woman. She has two children, ages 2 and 6 years. She describes herself as a determined woman.

Ngerechi operates a retail store, where she provides a service of grinding maize into flour with her posho mill and sells the maize flour to customers. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located at a busy area and her primary customers are local residents.

She says that her biggest business challenge is insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy maize for grinding into flour for sale. Her business goal is to run a stable business, within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will improve her business and her family's living standard. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy maize for grinding into flour for sale

loans.name: Anisa

texts.en: Anisa is 41 years old, married, and has five children. She sells used clothes and has been in business for the past ten years. She also practices farming. She is a very hard-working and honest lady. She has learned how to save her money for future purposes. She hopes to expand her business and open up a wholesale business. She requests a loan of 27,084 KES to buy more second-hand clothes.

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothes for resale to her customers

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 50 years old, married, and has three children.  She lives and runs a charcoal business in the village of Mwambalazi.  Fatuma began her business with a notions store, selling charcoal from home.  Later she moved to a larger area of retail.  So far, it has gone very well for her.  Over the years, she has built a loyal, dependable customer base.

Fatuma is requesting this loan in order to buy sacks of charcoal so that she can continue to stock her store well.  This way, she will be able to meet her customers’ needs.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Zurab

texts.en:
Zurab is 60 years old and lives in the Vani district.  He is married and lives with his wife.  The family runs a dairy farm of four milk cows and a calf, whose milk is used in cheese products.  The cheese is sold at the local open market.  In addition, Zurab owns a plot of land where nuts are grown.  He sells an average of 200-300 kg nuts per month.  In addition, he purchases chicks in the spring that he raises and sells as hens for a good price.  Zurab is a hardworking man who is responsible and very well known in the area for his big heart and friendliness toward others. 
 
Zurab requested a loan to purchase chicks in order to start poultry farming.  Zurab will raise chickens and then sell the hens at a good price.  He considers his business to be profitable, since it generates a good income that enables him to improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to purchase chicks.

loans.name: Lisset  De Los Santos

texts.es: Doña Lisset, de 36 años de edad, es cliente Kiva, quien se dedica al negocio de pulpería., negocio que comparte con  su familia. Su segundo préstamo le fue de mucho beneficio ya que logro comprar todos los producto que aun no tenia en inventario, como granos básicos, pasta dental, papel higiénico, pollo, gaseosa y la vitrina  para poder exhibir sus productos.  Ya que antes no tenia mucho capital con que trabajar, y el financiamiento llegó cuando mas lo necesitaba, logro pagar su segundo crédito satisfactoriamente. Siempre lucha por mantener su negocio con productos mas solicitado por sus clientes,  para poder incrementar sus ventas. Hoy está necesitando  su tercer financiamiento para comprar productos lácteos como leche, crema y embutidos como salchichas, mortadela, etc. Con el objetivo de agregar productos nuevo a su pulpería.
texts.en:
Lisset is 36 years old and has worked with Kiva before.  She works running a convenience store, which she shares with her family.  

Her second loan was very helpful, since it let her buy all the goods that she didn't have in her inventory at the time.  These included basic grains, toothpaste, toilet paper, chicken, soda, and a display case to show off her products.

Considering that beforehand she didn't have much money to work with and the loan came when she needed it most, she was able to pay off her second loan satisfactorily.  She always strives to stock her business with the products that are the most popular with her customers in order to increase her sales.

Today she is in need of her third loan in order to buy dairy products such as milk and crema (similar to sour cream) as well as cold cuts such as sausage, mortadela (a bologna-like meat), etc.  Her objective is to add new products to her convenience store.

loans.use: buy dairy products such as milk and crema (similar to sour cream) and also cold cuts such as sausage, mortadela (a bologna-like meat), etc.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice, 34 years old and a mother of one child, has a boutique in Nairobi's Eastland area. She sells several varieties of clothes which include suits and shirts for men and women as well as dresses for the children. She has been in the business for three years, and it has been profitable.

This is her first loan, and she plans to use the amount to buy more stock of clothes for resale. These include trousers and shirts for men as well as blouses and skirts for women. She anticipates making more income with which she will use to pay school fees for her child.

Beatrice hopes to grow her business by adding more variety of clothes and shoes for resale.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Paatita  Ole

texts.en:
Paatita repaid his previous loan due to the good harvest of the previous season.  He has now been advanced a loan of 80,000 KES which he will use to buy seedlings, fertilizers, and to pay for the preparation of land for the next planting season.

He hopes to use the anticipated profits to expand his business.  He hopes to buy a bigger plot as well as to own his own tractors for large-scale farming.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Kanga

texts.en:
Kanga is married and has eight children, all of whom attend school. With much hard work and dedication, she was able to open a small store in her home eight years ago. Since then, she has built a wide customer base since hers is the only comparable store in her neighborhood, and she is sure to always keep it well-stocked. It is a sacrifice to get up at dawn each day to go out to the market, where prices are best and food is freshest, in order to buy items to stock her store.

With this business, Kanga has been able to improve her home and to pay for her children's education. She is requesting this loan in order to buy vegetables, fruits, baked goods and other items to stock her store. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, fruits, baked goods and other items to stock her store.

loans.name: Benita

texts.es: La  Sra. Benita tiene 28 años, casada tiene tres  hijos de las edades de 13,  8 y 3 años dos de ellos se encuentran en edad escolar, ella se dedica a tejido de chompas de niños, bebes y mantas  para las mujeres de pollera, tiene su taller y domicilio en la zona de  Marcelo Quiroga, este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución, La  Sra. Benita va a usar este préstamo para la compra de lana por mayor para el tejido de sus chompas y mantas ya que por esta fechas tiene mucha venta también entrega pedidos a los distintos mercados de la ciudad de El Alto, su razón para solicitar este préstamo es incremento de capital de trabajo, La  Sra. Benita enfrenta retos en su negocio que son surtir su mercadería y va a utilizar los beneficios e seguir comprando por mayor sus materiales para el tejido de sus chompas.
texts.en:
Benita is 28 years old, is married, and has three children (ages 13, 8, and 3).  Two of them are of school-age.  She works knitting sweaters for children and infants, and cloth to make polleras (traditional multi-layered skirts).  She has her work space and home in the Marcelo Quiroga neighborhood.  

This loan is her first with Kiva.  Benita is going to use this loan to buy wholesale wool in order to knit sweaters and cloth, since she makes a lot of sales during this time of year.  In addition, she takes orders to different markets in the city of El Alto.

Her reason for asking for this loan is to increase her working capital.  Benita confronts challenges in her business that include stocking her merchandise.  She will use the profits and continue buying her supplies wholesale for knitting sweaters.

loans.use: buy wool to knit sweaters.

loans.name: Ebutuku Group

texts.en:
Irene’s group has 10 farmers and is located in Kakamega South District. Irene is pictured on the right, amongst 10 women of her group, Ebutuku Group, with her hand raised. She will receive input loans capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum, millet, and maize. Irene first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2010 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Irene joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and grow enough food for the family.

Irene reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about 2 bags of maize per acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested 9 bags per acre. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and save to buy another piece of land. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Irene’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 5 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia, 35, is married to Josephat who is a businessman. They have 2 children, and Sophia and her husband are always working to give them the best.

Sophia was previously as a farmer. Later she started buying and selling fruits and vegetables. Today she is very pleased with everything she has accomplished, because she was able to build a commercial space at the front of her house where she set up a store that is well-stocked with fruits and vegetables, and she says that she has a very good customer base. 

She is requesting a loan to buy consumer staples so that she can stock up her store with good products. She wants to buy drinks, bread, fruits, vegetables and other products.

loans.use: to buy drinks, bread, fruits, vegetables and other products.

loans.name: Gordon

texts.en:
Gordon is a 32 year old man, married, and supports three children whose ages are nine, seven and three years old.

Gordon operates an electrical shop. He is an electrician, and he also sells phone accessories. Gordon has been doing this business for the last 6 years and comfortably makes a monthly income of KES. 85,000. He is taking his third loan with KADET LTD which he will use to purchase phone chargers, battery capes, screws, etc. He has built a strong hope with KADET LTD . He will use the anticipated profit to increase the volume of his stock and the rest to pay school fees.

He has a dream of opening another business.

loans.use: to purchase phone chargers, battery capes, screws, etc.

loans.name: Ummi

texts.en:
Ummi is a 36 year old resident of Likoni, Kenya. She is married with two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with together with her husband.

Ummi's major monthly expenditure is school fees payment because both of her children are in school. She earns her living through selling clothes in a stall she established six years ago. She wishes to expand her stall and buy bundles of clothes, that is why she approached with a loan request amounting to Ksh.25,000. 

She is grateful for the opportunity.

loans.use: to buy bundles of clothes to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret, 35, is a merchant. She makes a living selling mainly fruits and vegetables. She has done this work for more than 4 years and she has a place in a popular market in the village where she sells fresh products to her customers every day.

She's a very hardworking person who makes an effort every day from very early in the morning, because she begins her work day very early.

She's requesting this loan to be able to buy fruits and vegetables so she can continue working and giving her customers good products.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Lucas

texts.en: Lucas is a married man. He has four children. He describes himself to be a courageous man. He operates a retail store where he provides tailoring services. He has been involved in this business for six years. His business is located in a competitive business area and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. He will use the KES 70,000 loan to buy fabric for making new clothes to sell. His business goal is to expand his business within five years. This is his fifth loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy fabric to make new clothes to sell

loans.name: Mayasa

texts.en:
Mayasa is from Mwambalazi, Kenya. She's a merchant and the owner of a food stall. She has been doing this work for more than five years and she has become very well known among the customers who go there.

Mayasa's a person with a lot of enthusiasm who likes to get ahead. That's why she works so hard. She works from very early in the morning to prepare the dishes she sells, and she returns home late at night.

She's requesting this loan to be able to buy beverages and supplies for her dishes. This is what she most needs and uses every day.

She's grateful for this opportunity because with it she's making progress.

loans.use: to buy beverages and supplies for her dishes.

loans.name: Idah

texts.en:
Idah is a 37 year old married woman, and she has 7 children. She describes herself to be God fearing, honest and self disciplined. 

She operates a retail store where she sells items such as bread, maize flour, sugar, salt, cooking fat etc. Her business is located at a strategic business area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving her business. 

She will use the Kes 8,700 loan to buy a water tank which will be used by her family members. Her business goal is to expand her business within 5 years. In addition, Idah does tailoring and poultry farming which increases her business income. She plans to start a new business of a boutique in the future. This is her third loan with SMEP DTM after managing to pay a loan of Kes 40,000 previously.

loans.use: to buy a water tank

loans.name: Sara Amparo

texts.es:
La señora Sara Amparo vive en la cuidad de Managua se caracteriza por ser una mujer trabajadora que siempre ha trabajado, su jornada de trabajo empieza a al cinco de la mañana  en un tramo de mercado mayoreo de la capital donde le llevan el producto que ella vende.

Doña Sara solicito  un crédito para invertirlo en la compra  de una cosecha de mango y jocote ya que  se aproxima la semana santa   y aumenta las  venta por que es una de las frutas que los nicaragüenses acostumbramos a echarle al tradicional almíbar, Que se elabora en los días santos.
texts.en:
Sara Amparo lives in the city of Managua.  She describes herself as a hardworking woman who has always worked.  Her work day begins at 5 in the morning at a stretch of wholesale markets in the capital, where she takes the goods that she sells.

Sara asks for a loan to invest in buying a crop of mango and jocote (a native fruit), since it is almost La Semana Santa ("Holy Week").  During this time, her sales increase because these are some of the fruits that nicaraguans commonly use to make a traditional syrup that is made for holy days.

loans.use: buy ayote (a hard squash), quequisque (a native root), jocote (a native fruit), mango, and papaya.

loans.name: Mapambano Group

texts.en:
Alice is a member of the Mapambano Group in Kakamega's South District. She is pictured with eleven One Acre Fund farmers: nine women and two men. Alice is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for a 1/2 acre of maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Alice joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2010 and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Alice joined One Acre Fund so that she could gain access to hybrid seeds and fertilizer and access the best input prices.

Alice reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about one bag of maize per 1/2 acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during Long Rains 2012, she harvested four bags per 1/2 acre. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive 1/2 an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Alice’s group will receive 5 1/2 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum

loans.name: Ligia Maria

texts.es: Ligia a sus 19 años labora como responsable de almacén, su salario es muy bajo pero ella hace el gran esfuerzo de pagar sus estudios universitarios la  carrera de contabilidad pública y auditoria, pero le da muchos ánimos el saber que está a unos meses de finalizar su carrera, pero necesita pagara el curso de titulación por lo que acude a Afodenic a solicitar financiamiento para hacer posible dicho pago, ya con titulo en mano sus aspiraciones a un mejor ingreso económico podría ser posible en muy corto plazo.
texts.en: Ligia is 19 years old and works as a warehouse manager.  Her salary is very low but she makes a great effort to pay for her university studies to become an accountant.  She is very motivated to know that she only has a few months left to finish, but she still needs to pay for a titles course, so she approached Afodenic to request a loan so she can make the payment.  With her title in hand she will be able to have a better income in a very short time.

loans.use: to pay tuition.

loans.name: Khvicha

texts.en: Khvicha is 21 years old. He lives with his mother and brother in the small village of Tskaltubo district, West Georgia. The family is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, they have two milk cows and two calves, whose milk is used in cheese production. Besides this, he has 0.3 hectares of agricultural land, where maize is grown. They sell cheese and harvested maize locally at a good price. Khvicha is very hardworking young man and does his best to ensure a good harvest. He requested a loan for renovating the shed for the cattle. After the shed is renovated, the family will be able to implement their future plans and expand the cattle. This will increase the income of the family and they will improve their living conditions. Khvicha awaits your support.

loans.use: to renovate the cattle shed

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah is a 59-year-old married woman. She has six children with ages ranging from 15 to 30 years. She describes herself as a determined woman. She operates a farm stand where she sells maize and beans. She has been involved in this business for 30 years. Her business is located in a fertile environment  and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of funds for improving the business. 

Hannah will use the KES 40,000 loan to buy farm products and pay employees. Her business goal is to improve her business within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will use her profits to educate her children. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM after managing to pay a loan of KES 20,000 successfully.

loans.use: to buy farm products and pay employees.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha lives in Mwambalazi and has a food stall business in her home. She says that she has an established clientele. In addition, Mwanasha states that her husband is a farmer.

She is an enterprising person who looks to provide better stability for her family each day. Mwanasha and her husband want to provide the best for their family, so they strive to make this happen. Her goal is to continue growing and expanding her shop.

Mwanasha is requesting a loan so that she can invest in the purchase of beverages, vegetables, fruits, milk, and other products to keep her food pantry stocked.

loans.use: to purchase beverages, vegetables, fruits, milk, and other products.

loans.name: Anastasia

texts.en:
Anastasia is quite happy of the progress she sees and believes its only a matter of time before she starts getting major harvests from the tea trees. It is in line with this that she has decided to invest more into her farming.

Anastasia is now asking for a loan of 13,012 Kenya shillings to purchase additional stock of tea tree seedlings for planting.

loans.use: to purchase tea tree seedlings.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph  is a married man. He has three children with ages ranging from four years to ten years. He describes himself as a determined and caring man. He operates a retail store where he sells charcoal. He has been involved in this business for nine years. His business is located in a competitive business area and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge as a lack of funds for improving the business. He will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy charcoal to sell. His business goal is to expand his business within five years. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy charcoal to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace, age 35, is a merchant who sells clothes. She is a widow, and lives with her three children. Grace began selling in the marketplace using her savings from her farming business. Gradually she was able to increase her business and now she offers her products throughout the district.

Grace travels to Mombasa town and brings back articles of clothing, which allows her to continue offering good prices. The articles of clothing that she sells mostly are those for women and children such as blouses, t-shirts, shorts, sweatshirts, and lingerie. She is requesting assistance so that she can buy articles of clothing that are in season. Grace wants to be well-stocked with these items so that she can offer them to her customers.

loans.use: to buy blouses, t-shirts, shorts, sweatshirts, and lingerie.

loans.name: Bubaare Women's Group

texts.en:
Bubaare women’s group is located in the middle of Ibanda town. The group comprises of only women whose major activity is small scale trade. They fall into different categories including divorcees, widows, single mothers and a few who are married. 
Flavia is a single mother of five children, all of whom are in school. She also looks after her two nephews who are orphans. She lost her husband in a car accident two years ago. Flavia is a small scale trader who sells vegetables in a local market with capital of 100,000 UGX. She supplements her vegetable business with her poultry farm which she resorted to after losing her husband in 2010 so that she could look after her children and take them to school which she does single handedly.
She will use the loan to buy more chickens to rear, to buy more stock to expand her vegetable business and also to pay school fees. The main challenge for Flavia is theft around the village and wild animals which eat her chickens after she has invested her money in them. This affects her working capital. Sometimes she and her children fall sick which reduces labor to work on her businesses. Despite all the challenges, Flavia is a very hardworking and determined woman looking forward to changing the future of her children by giving them a good education.

loans.use: To buy chickens for rearing and vegetables.

loans.name: Mushirongo Group

texts.en:
Nancy is a member of Mushirongo Group in Kakamega South District, a group consisting only of women. She is pictured with her group; Nancy is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Nancy joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season. Nancy joined One Acre Fund so that she could gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and access the best input prices.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Nancy was only able to harvest one bag of maize per acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, she was able to harvest eight bags per acre. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and repair her home. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Nancy’s group will receive five acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet and sorghum.

loans.name: Beth

texts.en: Beth is a married woman. She has four children with ages ranging from three years to 17 years. She describes herself as honest and trustworthy. She operates a retail store where she sells charcoal. Beth has been involved in this business for three years. Her business is located in a competitive business area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge as insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the 20,000 KES loan to buy charcoal to sell. Her business goal is to run a big charcoal retail store within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is 31 years old, a mother of four children aged between four and eight years old, all of whom attend school. She comes from Katito in the western part of Kenya.

Lilian is a hardworking lady, she operates a boutique shop which also has a beauty salon in it. She comfortably makes a monthly income of 80,000 KES. She is taking her third loan with KADET LTD, which she will use to buy more stock and equipment like a drier and other items for the salon.

She has a dream of opening a big boutique shop in Katito.

loans.use: to buy a drier and other items for the salon.

loans.name: Epiphanie

texts.en: Epiphanie is 36 years old. She owns a butcher shop. She has been selling meat for the past five years. With the loan, she wants to buy more meat to sell. With the profits from the business, she wants to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: To buy more meat to sell in her butcher shop.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is a client of Yehu Microfinance. She has been married to Yego for several years. Monica has had a food market for the last four years. She is asking for this loan to buy beverages, baked goods, sugar and tea to offer a wider variety of goods to her customers. With a greater variety of products to offer her customers, she will earn a larger profit margin which will help her improve her and her entire family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to buy beverages, baked goods, sugar and tea.

loans.name: Katherine Elizabeth

texts.es: Katherine es una joven que busca como salir adelante, en la actualidad está estudiando el último año de la escuela secundaria y también cursa una carrera técnica en administración turística y hotelera, ansia ir a la universidad para terminar su técnico en licenciatura, no está trabajando pero aprovecha al máximo su tiempo dedicándose al estudio ya que su madre le apoya con los gastos de estudios, como parte de su desarrollo necesita comprar una computadora por lo que está solicitando el crédito para hacer sus trabajos de investigación y otras tareas que le encomiendan en clases.
texts.en: Katherine is a young woman who is seeking ways to get ahead.  Currently, she is in her last year of high school and also studying tourism and hotel administration for a technical degree.  She is excited about going to the university to get her degree and spends most of her time studying.  She does not work so her mother helps cover education expenses.  As part of her development she needs to buy a computer.  She is requesting a loan so she can do the research and other work assigned in class.

loans.use: To buy a computer.

loans.name: Magna

texts.es:
La Sra. Magna de 38 años está casada con el Sr. Crispin, quien tiene dos camiones que están trabajando,  uno en la compra y venta de reciclados y otro en el Servicio de desagües cloacales.
Magna se dedica al comercio y tiene una despensa donde se dedica a la venta de artículos de primera necesidad como azúcar, panificados, lácteos, carnes y productos a granel. Tiene hijos adolescentes que están estudiando y que le ayudan con los quehaceres de la casa y también la ayudan en el negocio. Magna cuenta que sus padres fueron los que le inculcaron al comercio y que todos sus hermanos también cuentan con sus negocios propios.
Magna solicita de este crédito para la compra de productos de primera necesidad para poder abastecer su negocio y de esa forma poder seguir surtiendo a sus clientes con todo lo que necesitan.
texts.en:
Magna, 38, is married to Crispin who has two trucks, one for buying and selling recycled goods and another for use in sewage system services.

Magna has a store where she sells basic needs items, such as sugar, bread, milk, meat and bulk goods.  She has adolescent children who are in school and help with the housework.  They also help with the store.  Magna says her parents were the ones who taught her the merchant trade and her siblings also have their own businesses.

Magna is requesting a loan to buy basic products for her store so she can continue offering her customers everything they need.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her store.

loans.name: Santa Catalina Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado Santa Catalina está en su ciclo número 1º del programa de comité de mujeres, donde todas trabajan y se ayudan por salir adelante. Están haciendo la encuesta de eliminación de pobreza, donde dos de las señoras se encuentran por debajo de la línea de pobreza.
Una de las integrantes es la Sra. Digna, ella mostró en su última encuesta de eliminación de pobreza tener un ingreso muy bajo, estando por debajo de la línea de la pobreza. Ella es una persona que desea salir adelante y es por eso que se esfuerza mucho, se dedica a la venta de ropas y por medio de este trabajo quiere aumentar sus ingresos.
Solicita este crédito para la compra de prendas de todo tipo, para poder seguir trabajando y ofreciendo buena variedad a sus clientes, este préstamo le permitirá invertir en su emprendimiento.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Santa Catalina" is in its first loan cycle through the women's program.  The members all work and help each other mutually to get ahead.  When taking the poverty elimination survey, it was found that two of the members are below the poverty line.

On the survey she took, one of the members, Digna, showed a very low income and was below the poverty line.  She wants to get ahead and is working hard to do so.  She sells clothing and wants to increase her income.

She is requesting a loan to buy all kinds of clothing so she can keep working and offer a wide variety of goods to her customers.  This loan will allow her to invest in her business.

loans.use: To buy clothing to sell.

loans.name: Virgen De Itati Group

texts.es:
Este grupo de la ciudad de Encarnación surgió por promociones realizadas en la zona, trabajan con la fundación desde el año 2010 y están en su ciclo numero 10. Son mujeres jefas de familia, que se esfuerzan por salir adelante, ayudar a sus familias y darles una vida digna sin privaciones.
Una de las integrantes del grupo es la Sra. María, ella se dedica a la venta de comidas en forma ambulante, y cuenta que ya tiene muy buena clientela gracias a las delicias que prepara, es una persona con mucho talento para la cocina y es por eso que le va muy bien. Ella solicita de esta ayuda para poder invertir en insumos para poder seguir haciendo sus alimentos, como ser carnes, verduras, condimentos y demás, ya que esto la ayudará mucho.
El grupo agradece por la oportunidad que están recibiendo, ya que les será de mucha ayuda.
texts.en:
This group is from the city of Encarnación and came about as a result of promotions being conducted in the area.  The members have been working with the foundation since 2010 and are on their 10th loan cycle.  The women are heads of family who struggle to get ahead so they can help their families and give them a decent life that is not underprivileged.

One of the members of the group is María, who sells food as a street vendor.  She says she has a very good clientele because of her delicious dishes.  She is a talented cook so business is going very well.  She is requesting a loan to buy supplies so she can continue her business.  She will buy meat, vegetables, condiments and other items which will help her business.

The group is grateful for this opportunity as it will benefit the members greatly.

loans.use: To buy meat, vegetables, condiments and other items.

loans.name: Blas

texts.es:
El señor Blas tiene 27 años, es soltero, está en pareja y tiene un hijo de apenas unos meses. Blas cuenta que desde niño trabajó en un taller de motos donde fue adquiriendo conocimiento de la actividad, años después y gracias a la ayuda de familiares pudo juntar un capital con el cual pudo montar su propio taller y hace como 3 años aproximadamente tiene una casa de repuestos, así les brinda a sus clientes mayor comodidad y rapidez para el reparo de sus motocicletas.
El préstamo solicitado será destinado para la compra de más repuestos, con los que podrá seguir teniendo buena variedad que dar a sus clientes. Agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya y a Kiva por la oportunidad que está recibiendo, ya que le será de gran ayuda.
texts.en:
Blas is 27, single, and he and his partner have a child who is only a few months old.  Blas says that since he was a boy he has always worked in a motorcycle shop where he learned about the business.  Years later, and thanks to help from family, he was able to get together enough capital to start his own business.  Approximately three years ago he set up his repair shop to offer customers an easier, quicker repair service for their motorcycles.

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy more spare parts so he can offer more variety to his customers.  He is grateful to the Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva for this opportunity, as it will be of great help to him.

loans.use: To buy spare parts to sell.

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.en: Jacqueline is 32 years old. She sells different items in the boutique which she has been running for ten years. With the loan she wants to buy more lotions, basins, saucepans and plates to sell. With the profits from the business, she plans to build a house.

loans.use: To buy more lotions, saucepans, basins and plates to sell.

loans.name: Liliane

texts.en:
Liliane is aged 30. She sells food stuffs and has been in the business for the last five years. 

She wants the loan to buy more sweet potatoes, beans and sorghum to sell. With the profits from the business, she plans to renovate her house.

loans.use: To buy more sweet potatoes, beans and sorghum to sell.

loans.name: Vianney

texts.en:
Vianney is 26 years old. He sells hand bags and has spent four years in the business. 

With the loan, he wants to buy more hand bags to sell. The profits from the business will be used to buy a house.

loans.use: To buy more hand bags to sell.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a 32-year-old married woman. She has three children with ages ranging from one year to 13 years. She describes herself as an ambitious woman. She operates a retail store where she sells milk and retail products. She has been involved in this business for seven years. Her business is located in a potential business area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. 

She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy home products and milk to sell. Her business goal is to run multiple retail shops within five years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy home products and milk to sell.

loans.name: Sokol

texts.en:
Sokol is thirty-eight and married with three children who are 15, 13 and 11 years old. They are Roma and live in the south-central part of Albania, in the suburbs of a main city.  

For the past ten years, Sokol has been operating a repair shop for home electrical appliances. He runs the business from his house, as seen on the photograph. “At times, it is difficult working under such primitive conditions, like I have been. Yet not paying for rental saves me money, so I am okay for now. Later on, I will have to invest in building a little store,” Sokol said. “I lived in Greece for long time and this is where I learned the skills relevant to what I do. I am extremely grateful to my former Greek boss,” he added.

The loan Sokol is requesting from VFA is to buy parts for used appliances and the amount is 150,000 Albanian Lek.

loans.use: To buy parts from used appliances.

loans.name: Fagilia Group

texts.en:
Fagilia is a group of 20 farmers in Kakamega South District represented by Lilian. The group has 8 women and 2 men. Lilian is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum. Lilian first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Lilian joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and access the best input prices.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Lilian was only able to harvest 7 bags of maize per 2 ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains, she was able to harvest 10 bags per acre. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Lilian’s group will receive 5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Tabisa's Group

texts.en:
Tabisa's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Tabisa is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past two years, Tabisa has been working hard to manage her poultry farm, which sells chicken birds. 

To help expand her business, Tabisa has requested a loan of 350,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more chicks and feed for them, and will help Tabisa to generate greater profits and support her family with the basic needs. Tabisa hopes that in the future she will be able to increase further her capital. 

Tabisa is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more chicks and feed for them.

loans.name: Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Linet is a member of Tumaini Group in Kakamega South District. She is pictured with 12 One Acre Fund farmers, 10 women and 2 men. Linet is standing on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Linet first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Linet joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and to use the increased profits to send her children to school.

Linet reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about 3 bags of maize per 3/4 acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during the 2012 Long Rains, she harvested 12 bags per 3/4 acre. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to send her children to school and repair her home. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Linet’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 6 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Hasifa

texts.en:
Hasifa  is a single mother of two children. Both her children go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She has a business selling fruits and vegetables. She has been in this business for 11 years. 

She has applied for a loan of Uganda shillings 500,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy more baskets of cabbages, onions, tomatoes, oranges, mangoes and pineapples. She works at the market seven days a week and sells on retail only. Her major business challenges include seasonality and perishabilty. 

She aspires to becoming a wholesaler and also to start growing some fruits like oranges, mangoes and pineapples. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees, rent and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of oranges, mangoes, pineapples, onions, cabbages and tomatoes.

loans.name: Ushindi Group

texts.en:
Ushindi Group is located in Kakamega South District. It is a group of 10 women and 5 men led by Arthur pictured on the right with his hand raised. He is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Arthur first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Arthur joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and use the increased profits to send his children to school.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Arthur was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize per ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains, he was able to harvest 6 bags per ½ acre. He plans on using future profits from the harvest to send his children to school and perhaps invest in another business. Arthur’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total they will receive inputs for 7.5 acres of maize and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Veri

texts.en:
Veri, living in a major city of the south-central part of the country, is a 27-year-old single Roma man who plans on getting married soon and down the road repairing his run-down family home.

While Veri has been buying and reselling used items for the past five years, he has also been doing seasonal work in construction in Italy and Greece since he turned eighteen years old. With the economy slowing down lately in both countries, he decided to stay in Albania permanently and pursue his activity buying and selling used clothes, appliances and home-ware. 

Veri is requesting his first loan to purchase used home electrical appliances to resell.

loans.use: To purchase used home electrical appliances to resell.

loans.name: Alphonsine

texts.en:
Alphonsine is 31 years old. She sells various items in her boutique. She is married to a businessman. 

With the loan, she wants to buy more cooking oil and sodas to sell. The profits from the business will be used to build her home.

loans.use: To buy more cooking oil and sodas for re-sale.

loans.name: Pascasie

texts.en:
Pascasie is aged 48. She sells construction materials and has spent eight years doing this. 

She wants the loan to buy more iron sheets and doors to sell. With the profits, she wants to reinvest in the same business.

loans.use: To buy more construction supplies for re-sale.

loans.name: Ebuhanza Group

texts.en:
Jared is a member of Ebuhanza Group in Kakamega South District. He is pictured with 13 One Acre Fund farmers, 9 women and 4 men. Jared is standing on the right with his hand raised. He is receiving an input loan for ½ acre of maize, millet, and sorghum cultivation. Jared first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Jared joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and use the increased profits to send his children to school.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Jared was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize per 1 ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains, he was able to harvest 12 bags per 1 ½ acre. He plans to use the money that he earns from his next harvest to repair his home and save for the future. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Jared’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 6.5 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Rapha Group

texts.en:
Rapha Group is located in Kakamega South District. It is a group of 10 women led by Romona pictured on the right with her hand raised. She is receiving an input loan for ½ an acre of maize, millet and sorghum cultivation. Romona first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Romona joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and use increased profits to send her children to school.

Romona reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about 1 bag of maize per ½ acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan during the 2012 Long Rains, she harvested 4 bags per 1/2 acre. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and save for the future. Romona’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total they will receive inputs for 5 acres of maize and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 30 years old. She sells charcoal and has been in the business for six years. With the loan, she wants to buy more charcoal to sell. The profits from the business will be used to expand her business through reinvesting in the existing business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Sisi Kwa Sisi Group

texts.en:
Susan’s group has 10 farmers and is located in Kakamega South District. Susan is pictured on the right of Sisi Kwa Sisi Group with her hand raised. Susan is pictured amongst the one man and nine women of her group. She will receive input loans capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum, millet and maize. Susan first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2010 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Susan joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and access the best input prices.

Susan described her harvest as poor last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Susan’s group will receive 5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Francine

texts.en: Francine is 42 years old. She is married with five children aged between 8 and 15; they all go to school. She sells charcoal and has been in the business for two years. Her husband does not have a specified job. She plans to use the profits to provide food for the family.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Tembiapo Pora Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado Tembiapo Pora  está en su ciclo número 11. A través del esfuerzo y el trabajo continuo, ellas se encuentra mejorando su situación de pobreza, pero igualmente está consciente de que este trabajo y esfuerzo que está haciendo debe ser continuo.
Agueda, una de las miembros de este grupo, comenta que por medio de la compra y venta de cosméticos está saliendo adelante y ayuda con esto a su familia. Agueda es una persona muy trabajadora y esta consiente que por medio de su trabajo podrá mejorar sus ingresos e ir creciendo.
Solicita de este crédito para la compra de cosméticos de toda clase, para poder seguir trabajando y ayudando así a su familia. Agradecen por la oportunidad que reciben, porque seguirán creciendo.
texts.en:
This group, called "Tembiapo Pora", is on its eleventh loan cycle.  Through efforts and continuous work, the women are improving their financial situation but, at the same time, they are aware that their efforts and work must continue.

One member of the group, Agueda, says that by buying and selling cosmetics she is moving forward and so she can help her family.  Agueda is a hard-working person and knows that, through her work, she can increase her income and keep growing.  

She is applying for this loan to buy all types of cosmetics, so as to continue working and continue helping her family.  The group members are thankful for the opportunities that they are given because with them they will keep growing.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Кумри

texts.ru: Кумри  профессиональная доярка. Раньше работала в городском молочном заводе, доила коров. Имеет множество наград и грамот. Как сама вспоминает: «были хорошие времена. Коров  было много, и все давали густое, вкусное молоко. Я была передовиком и доила по 110 литра молоко каждый день, ухаживала за коровами. У коров даже были свои имена. С того момента у меня остались увлечение к животноводству». Кумри как и многие другие осталась без работы, когда закрыли завод. Наступили трудные времена и она решила создать свою маленькую ферму. В этот момент десятилетний опыт пришёл ей в помощь. Она  приобрела пару крупного рогатого скота , доила их и продавала молоко. Этим зарабатывала на хлеб. Муж всячески помогал ей, он разводил и кормил коров. Благодаря своему трудолюбию и оптимистичности Кумри смогла поставить на ноги своих троих маленьких детей. Но год назад из-за болезни одна корова умерла а другую пришлось продать из-за нужды в деньгах. Сейчас Кумри имеет одного КРС и хочет приобрести ещё одного. С этими намерениями обратилась в МДО «Арванд» за финансовой поддержкой. Она хочет разводить коров, доить их и продавать молоко, чтобы зарабатывать на проживания. И этим сможет как то сэкономить заработанные деньги мужа и делать заначку для будущего  своих детей. Кумри благодарит "Арванд", за то, что финансово помогают и поддерживают людей в трудный период их жизни.
texts.en:
Kumri is a professional milkmaid.  She used to work as a milker in the city dairy factory.  She has many awards and recognitions.  As she remembers, "those were good times.  There were many cows and the gave rich, tasty milk.  I was the lead worker and drew up to 110 liters of milk every day and looked after the cows.  The cows even had their own names.  Since then, I still have a passion for livestock."

Like many others, Kumri was left without work when the factory closed.  Tough times came and she decided to start her own small farm.  At that moment, her ten years of experience came in handy.  She bought two cows, sold their milk, and she began to earn a living this way.  Kumri's husband helped her with the raising and feeding of the cows.  Thanks to her her work and positive attitude, Kumri was able to raise her three small children.  But a year ago, she lost one cow to an illness and she had to sell the other because she needed the money.  Now Kumri has one cow and she wants to get another one.  With this goal in mind, she turned to "Arvand" for financial support.  She wants to raise livestock and sell their milk so she can earn a living.  That way, she will be able to put aside some of her husband's money to save for her children's future.  Kumri thanks "Arvand" for their financial help and for their support of people who are going through difficult times.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Wetinyia Group

texts.en:
Wetinyia is a group of 11 farmers in Kakamega South District represented by Margaret. The group has 9 women and 2 men. Margaret is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of maize, millet and sorghum. Margaret joined One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2010, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2013 season.  Margaret joined One Acre Fund so that she could grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send her children to school.

Margaret described her harvest as very good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to send her children to school and repair her home. Margaret’s group members will each receive input loans of ½ acre during the 2013 Long Rains season. In total they will receive inputs for 5.5 acres of maize and sorghum.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Amka Twende Group

texts.en:
Eliseba’s group has 14 farmers and is located in Kakamega South District. Eliseba is pictured on the right of Amka Twende Group with her hand raised.  Eliseba is pictured amongst the 2 men and 12 women of her group. She will receive input loans capable of planting ½ an acre with sorghum, millet and maize. Eliseba first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2012 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Eliseba joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send her children to school.

Prior to joining One Acre Fund, Eliseba was only able to harvest 1 bag of maize per ½ acre, but after joining One Acre Fund during the Long Rains 2012, she was able to harvest 9 bags per ½ acre. She plans on using future profits from the harvest to send her children to school and save for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Eliseba’s group will receive 7 acres worth of inputs on credit.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Opendo Group

texts.en:
Leonora is pictured on the right with her hand raised amongst her Opendo Group members. The 18 of them, 15 women and 3 men, are farmers in Kakamega South District. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of maize, millet, and sorghum. Leonora first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2010 Long Rains and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Leonora joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send her children to school.

Leonora described her harvest as very good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She plans to use the money that she earns from her next harvest to invest in cows and save for the future. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Leonora’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 9 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
